separated.—illi, a dat. rendered by from, instead of the abl. of separation; § 381 (229);G. 345. R. 1; H. 385. II. 2.
lacesseret: subjv. in indir. disc., following existimabat.
congredi, to form an alliance with.
praesidio: cf. 89 5.
tripartito: in three columns, on different roads.

Commium: appointed king of the Atrebates by Caesar (106 13-17). He served as Caesar's friend and ally in Britain and elsewhere, but finally joined in the great revolt against him (Bk. vii. ch. 76).—custodis loco, as a guard.
dum geruntur: the regular construction with dum cf. 113 1 and note.
in eorum finibus: see Bk. v. ch. 24.
via: abl. after longius.—cum … cognoscunt: not like the descriptive cum, but really the main proposition. See § 546.a (325.b); G. 581.
a (adverbial), away.
impedimentis: i.e. the greater part of the heavy baggage. He took a small baggage-train with him (see 161 28); but probably on what was necessary.
flumen: probably some stream flowing into the Meuse (Mosa), perhaps the AIzette.

transire, transituros: notice the regular use of these two constructions side by side: the first verb (habebat in animo) expresses intention and has the simple compl. infin.; the second (existimabat) is a verb of thinking and takes the indir. disc. This is one of the most important distinctions in Latin Grammar.
augebatur: i.e. in the minds of the Treveri.
spes, their (the Treveri) hope.—loquitur: i.e. Labienus.—palam, freely or openly, on purpose to be heard, but not in a set speech.
castra moturum: of course to withdraw.
natura: i.e. their natural attachment to their own land.
consili: pred. gen.; cf. 18 19.
cum: see note on 160 26.
longum esse, it would be tedious; § 437.a (264.b); G. 254. R. 1; H. 476. 5.
imperatori: Caesar, who alone had the imperium, or military authority. Labienus was only dux.
derigi: i.e. to be formed and aligned; the verb properly has only the latter meaning, the former is only implied.
celeriter, etc.: see chapter on military affairs, VII.

recepit, recovered to obedience.—auxillo; dat. of service.
>
comitati eos, in company with them (the Germans).
demonstravimus: see Bk. v. chs. 3, 4, and 56.
paulo supra, a little above, or to the south, probably near Andernach.
nota … ratione = on the plan already tried and approved (cf. Bk. iv. ch. 17).
cognita, having inquired into.
paucis post diebus: § 424.f (259.d); G. 403. N. 4; H. 430.
eis … imperio: subject tribes, not confederate allies. Tacitus, however (Ger. 38), represents the Suevi as a confederacy; its former subjects may, after Caesar's time, have been admitted to alliance.
quaeque: -que connects mittant and cognoscant.

silvam: this was the natural frontier and defence (pro nativo muro) of the north German plain towards the south. A range of wooded hills still borders the Saxon duchies on the north. The Cherusci held the valleys of the Weser and Elbe.

locum, etc.: here there is really nothing to tell, as Caesar found the country deserted (ch. 29), and returned at once to Gaul. We owe to this void in the narrative a most curious and entertaining glimpse into the geographic and ethnographic knowledge of the time. See the introductory chapters on Gaul and Germany.
existimantur: is only explanatory, hence the indic.
quorum: the antecedent is principes.

redeat: is characteristic (§ 535 (320); G. 631. I; H. 503. I). The idea seems to be: It is the chief men of these factions (those namely who are regarded as most influential) who have the supreme authority. Hence the effort of each of the chieftains to look out for his dependents. A good illustration is found in modern political bosses.
ne … egeret: in app. with eius rei, the past tense (egeret) taking its time from institutum [esse]: § 485.j (287.i, 336 B. N. 2); G. 518; H. 495. IV.
haec … Galliae, this same state of things exists in general throughout enitre Gaul.
divisae: adj. use of the participle; cf. divisa, 1 1.

cum … venit: notice the difference between this and the cum in descriptive clauses (cf. 11 7, 49 1). Here it means merely 'at the time when, etc.,' and there is no inner connection with the main clause.
Sequani: these succeeded to the domination of the Arverni (see Bk. i. ch. 31) —hi, the latter.
antiquitus: really only a little while before, as the Haedui had risen by favor of the Romans.
clientelae, dependencies. these were the petty tribes which grouped themselves about one or the other of the great rival states.
iurare: i.e. the Haedui.
nihil … consili, no plans, part. gen.—et: connects cogerent and possiderent.
Diviciacus: cf. 27 13.
infecta re, without effecting his object.

adventu Caesaris … dimiserant: this long Latin periodic sentence should in our idiom be rendered by several coordinate sentences (cf. note on 66 5).—facta commutatione: i.e. by his friendship to the Haedui and the defeat of Ariovistus (Bk. i. chs. 31-53).
ei: subj. of videbant.
reliquis rebus: abl. of specification.
adaequare, were equal; i.e. to the Haedui. (The infin. clause quos adaequare is the subj. of intellegebatur, which is used impersonally.)
gratia: abl. of specification.
d&ibreve;cabant: distinguish from dīcebant.
statu: loc. abl.
plebes: here a noun of the fifth declen.; cf. plebs.
cum … premuntur: a general condition expressing repeated action, cum meaning whenever or as often as. The perf. indict would be more usual; cf. 59 13, 131 7.
quae dominis (dat. of poss.), as masters have.
druidum (pred. gen.), that of the druids.—illi: the former.
hi: i.e. the druids.
eos: i.e. the Gauls.
quod facinus, any crime.
idem: nom. plural.
qui: why not quis ? Observe also si qui in l. 10 below.
sacrificiis: abl. of separation; understand eos with interdicunt.—poena: like an excommunication, taboo, or boycott.
decedunt (with dat.): sc. de via (i.e. 'make way for' them in the street).
incommodi: part. gen. following quid.
Carnutum: this central spot was at or near the modern town of Dreux, where, it is said, traces of these assemblies may still be found.

disciplina, system of doctrine; cf. meaning of the same word in 165 25.—Britannia: many think that druidism originated in Gaul and
was carried thence to Britain, where it still flourished, but that it had declined for various political reasons in the mother country.
The bracketed words merely repeat the thought of the preceding sentence and may be omitted.
numerum versuum: i.e. their lore was put into verse to assist the memory.
fas: the words fas and nefas refer to what is religiously right and wrong, in distinction from ius and iniuria, which refer to human obligations only.
litteris confisos, by trusting to written words, a useful hint to teachers.
hoc (acc.), more usually illud, refers to what follows; hoc (abl.) to what has just been said.
transire: the belief in the transmigration of souls was common to many ancient peoples, and is still a tenet of some Eastern religions, especially of the Buddhists.
mundi, the universe (system of things); terrarum (cf. orbis terrarum), the world.

equitum: these made a sort of military nobility. It is interesting to compare the two "upper classes" here described with the ecclesiastics and feudal noblesse of France before the Revolution.—cum est: notice the force of the indicative. See note on cum … premuntur, 165 18.—usus: a noun; see vocab.
ut quisque amplissimus … ita plurimos, the more powerful … the greater number (§ 313.b (93.c, at end); G. 642. R. 2; H. 458. 2).
ambactos: this Celtic word was known as the equivalent of servus "slave," as early as the time of Ennius, 150 years before. Cf. 165 16-21.
homines immolant: it is not certain that the practice of human sacrifice existed so late as this in Gaul. Caesar appears not to have known any actual instances of it.
plācārī: distinguish from placere.—publice: as opposed to the private ones just referred to.
habent instituta: cf. 40 20, 51 8, and notes.
cum … deficit: cf. cum est, 167 17.

Mercurium: the gods had no such names, nor were they, in fact, the same gods; but they were identified with similar Roman divinities as nearly as possible. The name of the god whom the Romans identified with Mercury is lost (Teutates?); but it appears from inscriptions and images that his worship was very widespread and important throughout the period of the Empire. The other deities here mentioned appear
under numerous epithets. Jupiter was probably the Gallic Taranis, whose name appears to indicate that he was a god of thunder. He has been identified by some with a statuette bearing in its hand a long hammer or mallet, like the Scandinavian Thor. (See Esquisse de la Religion des Gaulois, by Henri Gadioz.)
cum, etc.: see 165 18 and note.
ceperint: subjv. of informal indir. disc., for the fut. perf. inc. of the direct.
neglecta religione: i.e. in violation of his vow.—capta, taken as spoil.—apud se, at his house.
posita, consecrated as a gift.
Dite (see § 403.a.N.1 (244.a. R.); G. 395; H. 415. II. N.), Pluto, the god of Darkness, or of the Underworld, meaning that they believe themselves to have sprung from the soil, the world below them.

noctium, etc.: this usage is common to many primitive peoples; e.g. the Germans (Tact. Ger. II). Our word "fortnight " is a relic of it. It doubtless had its origin in keeping time by the changes of the moon.
ut … subsequatur: i.e. the calendar day began at sunset.

fere (with hoc): i.e. speaking loosely.—suos liberos, etc. The Romans, on the other hand, accustomed their sons to public life, and in early times even took them with them into the Senate. Again cum with the perf. ind. expressing repeated or customary action; cf. 168 20. Observe that this perf. becomes a present in our idiom, expressing repeated action or a general truth.
turpe ducunt, they consider it disgraceful, turpe being pred. adj. agreeing with the infin. clause.
quantas … communicant: i.e. the husband deposits, in a common fund, an amount equal to the wife's marriage portion.
ratio habetur, a reckoning is kept.
fructus, revenues or profts.—vita: abl. of specification.
viri in uxores, etc.: cf. the Roman patria potestas; the rank of the wife was much higher among the Germans.

de uxoribus: this would seem to imply polygamy among the Gauls. Probably it was limited to the chiefs, as among the Germans; see note on 48 6.—in servilem modum, after the manner of slaves, i.e. by torture.
compertum est: i.e. that there has been foul play.
excruciates interficiunt: cf. 5 5, 55 3, and notes.—pro cultu, considering the degree of civilization.
hanc = nostram (cf. 51 17), i.e. a generation ago.

dilectos: distinguish from delectos.—iustis, regular, by conventional rule. When these had been fulfilled, the sacrifice of dependents was added. These usages are in accordance with the belief of the Gauls in immortality, which is fully attested.
quae civitates = eae civitates quae; a relative clause standing first generally incorporates its antecedent.
legibus sanctum, established by law, agreeing with the sentence si … communicet (obj. of habent); cf. 40 20, 51 8.
neve, and that not, the regular connective for a negative purpose clause.—quo: indef., any one.
quod saepe, etc.: cf. the lively account 97 9-17.
quae visa sunt, what they think fit to conceal (understand occultanda).
per concilium, by means (or, in the proceedings) of the public assembly.
neque druides habent: i.e. this particular hierarchy. They had, however, both priests and priestesses, with religious forms public and private.

deorum numero, etc. In this, Caesar's testimony is directly contradicted by Tacitus, who speaks (Ger. 9) of their worship of Mercury, Mars, and Hercules. This is almost the only contradiction hetween these writers, in whose accounts of political and other institutions there is a striking agreement. This is all the more remarkable when we bear in mind that Caesar went but little beyond the German frontier and had relatively little to do with them. This description of the Germans may be profitably compared with Caesar's account of the Suevi in the opening chapters of Bk. iv.

a parvis, from childhood.—qui … permanserunt: i.e. " who are slowest to outgrow " their boyhood. Cf. Tacitus: sera juvenum venus, eoque inexhausta pubertas; and contrast the premature debaucheries of the Roman youth.
hoc: abl. of cause.
nulla occultatio: like the English there is no hiding.
renonum: i.e. small cloaks of hide.—magnā … nudā: abl. abs.

agri culturae: as to this chapter, cf. what is said in the general Introduction to the volume and in Bk. iv. ch. 1, where it is shown that the soil was tilled, not by the labor of old men, women, or slaves, but by that of the fighting men. In other words, the Germans were, though "barbarians," not (in one sense) a barbarous people.

neque quisquam, etc: this temporary and shifting occupation
of land, as well as the holding of it by the family or clan (cognationinbus) is characteristic of a primitive society. Cf. the Introduction, as above.
finis proprios, private lands.
gentibus, etc.: in the general gathering for this assignment, each clan must have met by itself, and have been represented by its chief.
quantum agri, as much land; agri is part. gen.

agri culturā: notice the use of the abl. (§ 416 (252); G. 404; H. 422. N. 2), here to be rendered "for."—ne … expellant: this was flagrant evil in Italy, which Caesar had attempted in his own consulship to check (by the lex agraria), following the precedent of the Gracchi. There the potentiores had already succeeded in ousting the humiliores from their estates, and creating enormous plantations, latifundia, cultivated by slaves in place of the earlier peasant freeholds.

cum … videat: this looks as if the land was portioned in equal shares to rich and poor alike. But on this question there are many and various opinions, and, at any rate, the words do not prove a division to each man as a freehold.
maxima laus: so in Bk. iv. ch. 3.
prope, near; consistere, to stay or settle. The infin. clauses are in app. with hoc.
cum … infert: note the force of pres. indict with cum; cf. 165 18 and note.
magistratus … deliguntur: by lot, according to the Saxon Bede, from among existing magistrates. The Goths, Burgundians, Franks, and Lombards, on the other hand, had real kings.
praesint, habeant: subjv. of characteristic.

principes … pagorum: these local and village chiefs, forming a sort of governing body, were probably the natural leaders each of his own district. They are said, however, to have been elected, no doubt for life, by an assembly of the tribe or nation (Tact Ger. 12).
latrocinia … extra finīs: as with the "cattle-lifting raids" of the Scottish Borderers.
ubi quis, etc., whenever any one, equivalent to the protasis of a general condition. This is the manner in which volunteers were mustered for the raids in question.
profiteantur: representing an imperat. form in the dir. disc.
omnium rerum fides, confidence in anything.
qui … venerunt: again the perf. indict in the protasis of a general condition,—whoever comes to them for any reason whatsoever; cf. 168 20.
cum … superarent: a clause of characteristic, such that, etc.; see § 535.a.N.3 (322.R.); G. 631. 2; H. 503. I. N. 2.
superarent, inferrent, mitterent: asyndeton, i.e. omission of connectives.
Hercyniam silvam: the great wooded range extending from the Black Forest to the Bohemian Highlands.—Graecis: i.e. other Greeks, as Eratosthenes was a Greek, though not of Greece proper.

Volcae Tectosages, etc.: occupying the southern part of Gaul, about Narbonne or Toulouse. A portion only had migrated to Germany; or, perhaps, had stayed behind from an early Celtic migration westward.
Gallis: indir. obj. of largitur, multa being the dir. obj.

iter: acc. of extent; cf. 98 3.—expedito (dat.): i.e. to a man unencumbered with baggage.—non … noverunt: i.e. the Germans who live there. So at the present day, in the mountain regions of Germany and Switzerland, distance is measured by "hours" (stunden) instead of miles.
Nemetum, etc.: along the middle course of the Rhine, where it flows northward from Bâle.—recta regione: i.e. parallel.
Dacorum, etc.: occupying the eastern and western portions of Hungary.
sinistrorsus: in reality it is the river which leaves the course of the forest or highland, bending abruptly to the right, or southward.
huius: that familiar to the Romans, viz. western.
[aut audisse]: may be omitted in translation.—initium: as we should say the end, eastward, where it is lost in the Carpathian range. Its extent, in a direct line, is stated as 1600 miles.
processerit: subjv. as an intermediate clause in inc. disc. for perf. indict
acceperit: subjv. of characteristic.
quae, such as, followed by the subjv. of characteristic.
differant: subjv. of characteristic.
bos: this name seems to have been given loosely to any large-horned, unfamiliar beast, and even to the elephant; here it is perhaps the reindeer, which had anciently a wide-scattered range.
unum cornu: this description is unintelligible.
palmae ramique (hendiadys; cf. note on 28 25), branching antlers, evidently comparing the horns to a flat hand with branches like fingers.
alces: this name is undoubtedly elks, but the description is widely unlike and quite unrecognizable.
crura … habent: the same story is told by Pliny, H. N. viii. 16, 39.
si … conciderunt: cf. 172 3 and note. By what tense should this perfect be rendered? The same construction occurs below in l. 20, cum est animadversum, and in l. 23, cum reclinaverunt.
omnes: with arbores.
ab radicibus, at the roots.—accīdunt, cut into.—tantum ut, etc.: lit. so far that the perfect appearance of them standing is left; translate, so that to all appearances they are standing firmly.

uri: this name is generally understood to refer to the German Urochs (the primitive or wild ox, probably buffalo), said still to be found in the forests of Lithuania. Caesar evidently describes a very different animal, with spreading horns like those of a reindeer or moose; but the whole description must have been derived from a confused account.
quae sint testimonio, to serve as evidence, a purpose clause.
ne … excepti, not even when caught quite young.
Caesar, etc. This chapter directly follows ch. 10 in the narrative, the intervening passage being a digression.
supra: see 170 26.

ne … tolleret: as would be done by completely destroying the bridge.—barbaris: dat. (§ 381 (229); G. 345. R. 1;H. 385. II. 2).—atque, and at the same time.—ut tardaret: which he did by making the bridge practically useless.
auxilia: i.e. which the Germans might send to aid the Gauls.

in extremo ponte. There seems to have been an island in the river at this place, so that the bridge was in two sections. The section between the island and the east bank was destroyed, and at what was now the end of the bridge (extremo), on the island, the tower was built. There was probably a redoubt, as usual, at the entrance to the bridge on the mainland; see Fig. 59.
cohortium: these were auxiliaries, as it appears in ch. 33 that he took all his legions with him.
cum maturescere, etc.: i.e. early in August.
Arduennam: the modern Ardennes (Shakespeare's Forest of Arden).
D: an obvious mistake, possibly of some copyist. The distance is about 150 miles.—Basilum: afterwards one of the conspirators against Caesar.
si … posses, (to see) whether he can, etc. (see § 576.a (334.f); G. 460. (b); H. 529. II. I. N 1).
qua: why not quae?
subsequi: notice the pres.for the fut.
multum potest, has great power; see note on 10 17.
nam ut, etc., for as it happened by a remarkable chance that, etc.; the following clause being subj. of accidit.—ipsum: referring to Ambiorix; so too in l. 12.
prius … quam: render as one word, before; in English we omit the relative particle.—eius: i.e. Basili.
videretur: in the same construction as incideret.—adferretur: cf. 158 24 and note.
magnae fortunae (pred. gen.), a great piece of luck.
hoc: abl. of means, explained by quod, etc.
sunt fere, generally are.
propinquitatīs: use the singular in English; see § 99 (75.c); G. 204. N. 5; H. 130. 2.

his pugnantibus: notice the force of the Latin order. While these were fighting, time was given for the chief to be placed on horseback by some of his followers, and, as soon as he actually got away, he was covered by the woods.
iudicione … an, whether by design … or, etc.
quas aestus: i.e. islands only at high tide.
alienissimis, entire strangers.
Catuvolcus: see 133 20-23, 134 17-19.
precibus detestatus, cursing with formal imprecations, which, from a dying man, were thought to have efficacy with the gods.
fuisset: informal indir. disc.—taxo: perhaps with a decoction of yew leaves, as the berries are said to be harmless.
neve: see note on 170 6.
unam esse causam, that the case was the same; i.e. that they were all included in the league.
convenissent, reducerentur: in dir. disc. convenerint, reducantur.

id castelli nomen est, that is the (German) name of a stronghold. It will be remembered that the Aduatuci were of German descent; and it is thought that Aduatuca is an old German word, meaning a stronghold. Then the Aduatuci would be the people who held such a place of safety. There were several towns of this name, which fact adds force to the conjecture.
Titurius, etc. (Sabinus and Cotta): see 133 20-24.
laborem: i.e. of making a new fortified camp.
unam ex his, etc.: see 158 4 ff.
Q. Ciceronem: see Bk. v. chs.39-52.
ad … versus, towards.

Scaldim, the Scheldt. There seems to be some confused
geography here, but the many and confused mouths of these rivers doubtless gave rise to this idea.
vii = septimum. Cf. a different idiom, 163 9.—quam ad diem: cf. 179 2 (quem ad diem). Observe that dies is often fem. when it means time.
frumentum deberi: see chapter on military affairs, IV. f.
commodo (abl.), to (properly in accordance with) the advantage, etc.—rei publicae: gen.; cf. 31 94, 148 18.
supra: in ch. 31.
quod se defenderet, capable of, etc. (subjv. of charateristic).
cuique, to each; notice the Latin idiom. We should put the distributive with the leading verb (consederat), each had taken position where, etc.
universis, to men gathered in one body.
ex parte, in a measure.

hominum sceleratorum, those scoundrels; an expression of temper which Caesar does not often permit himself towards his foes. It shows his bitter hatred against the hapless Eburones, who had destroyed his officers and legion.
vellet: not contrary to fact, but in both cases a future protasis thrown back into past time; cf. note on 141 1.
ut in, etc., considering that it was in, etc.; a not uncommon use of ut.

ut potius, etc.: we may translate so that some opportunities for doing injury were neglected, though the clause is properly one of purpose. Connect potius with quam. The thought is that Caesar's plan was to save the lives of his soldiers, even at the expense of neglecting to punish the enemy, and to employ others to carry out his vengeance.
ulciscendum: i.e. to avenge the destruction of the force Sabinus and Cotta (Bk. v. chs. 27-38).
noceretur (impers.), harm should be done to the enemy.
fortuna: cf. 175 7.—possit, adferat: present tense to express a general truth; though usually in Latin such expressions follow the sequence of tenses.
ultro, freely; i.e. any that would; as a general invitation extending beyond those immediately concerned.
supra docuimus: see 102 21-25.
primos finīs, the nearest limits.
paludes: subj. of morantur.
profectum: i.e. eum profectum esse.
Aduatucam: i.e. where Cicero with a single legion was guarding the baggage of the whole army; see ch. 32.
tantum, only so much, really, so feeble.
cingi, surrounded; i.e. manned (with a line of defenders).
duce, as guide (pred. app.).
Cicero: up to this time he had shown himself to be an unusually discreet and courageous officer.
continuisset (concessive subjv.), though he had, etc.
vii = septimo.—de numero: construe with fidem servaturum.
progressum: cf. profectum, 179 18.
illius, etc., who called his quiet waiting a blockade.
si quidem, since: with subjv., indicating the ground of their complaint.
quo (following eius modi, of such sort that), with posset as subjv. of result.—oppositis, had gone to meet the enemy; the abl. abs. expresses cause.
in milibus passuum tribus: i.e. within three miles of his camp.
offendi (impers.), an attack could be made.
quas inter: several prepositions sometimes follow their cases, especially those of two syllables.
hoc spatio: i.e. since Caesar's departure.

sub vexillo: here the vexillum was a little scarlet flag (quite distinct from the metal signum), used by small bodies detached for some special service. The name vexillarii was given to the soldiers of such a corps; see chapter on military affairs, II, and Figs. 121, 128.
calonum: i.e. officers' servants and grooms for the horses. These were slaves.—iumentorum: to bring in the expected supplies.
subsederat, had remained behind when Caesar left.—facta potestate, obtaining leave.
[et]: omit in translation.

ab decumana porta, at the rear gate (see Fig. 119). The camp fronted in the direction where the enemy were supposed to be, i.e. towards the Gallic tribes; so that its more exposed part lay nearest the German attack.
nec prius … quam, and not till; for the mood following, see 158 24 and note.

silvis: it was considered bad generalship to place a camp so near the woods as to conceal the approach of the enemy. The pickets, too, must have been either very carelessly stationed or very negligent.

usque eo, so close.—qui … mercatores, the traders who spread their booths (tentoria) under the shelter of the wall.—recipiendi sui: for construction, see § 504.c (298.a); G. 428. R. 1; H. 542. I. N. 1; cf. 40 15, 77 3, 77 20.
in statione: i.e. before the gate.
circumfunduntur: the middle or reflexive use of the passive, rendered in English by the active intransitive form; pour in or about.
si: interrog., [to see] whether; cf. 174 28.

signa, etc.: i.e. as the whole camp was in confusion the soldiers could not tell in which direction the line was to be formed (signa ferantur) nor where each man should rally (quisque conveniat). It is noticeable that Cicero is not spoken of after the beginning of ch. 36. Ordinarily this woulc be just the moment when a commander would be most active. It seems to show that he shared in the general panic.
imperatore: Caesar. Observe the force of atque: and the general, too!
novas religiones, a sudden superstition, as if the spot itself were unlucky to the Romans (see 176 20-22).
qui occiderint, who (as they recalled; hence subjv.) had fallen.
barbaris: dat. of reference.
apud Caesarem, with Caesar.
proeliis (abl. of time): see Bk. ii. ch. 25; Bk. iii. ch. 5.

consequuntur hunc: as primus pilus, he had authority to command all other centurions; although generally, as here, he really only formed a rallying point. See chapter on military affairs, I. 7
Figure 128. Tabernaculum. .
cohortis: cf. 180 23-25.
relinquit animus, his breath (or consciousness) fails him (he faints).
per manus traditus, passed along from hand to hand by his comrades.—hoc spatio: i.e. the time gained by this short resistance.
hic: i.e. in the open field.

modo … exspectant: the Roman discipline was so perfect that, in general, every man knew just what to do in any emergency (as in the fight with the Nervii, Bk. ii. ch. 21); but these new levies (see 176 24-27) were helpless till the exact order had been given, even the boldest of them (nemo est tam fortis, etc.).
legiones: those of Caesar and his legati; see ch. 33.
paucitate: i.e. five cohorts and the 300 convalescent veterans.
in signa manipulosque, among the cohorts and maniples. In their panic the servants rushed among the ranks of the cohorts (signa) and the maniples.
alii … alii: these seem to have had some presence of mind, as is implied in the expression censent, the regular expression for voting in a public assembly.
quoniam … sint, since [as they say], etc.
[confidunt]: may be omitted in translation, the infin. posse depending on the idea of saying involved in censent.—alii: sc. censent.
hoc: the latter counsel, which was that of the raw recruits.—docuimus: cf. 180 13-15.
C. Trebonio: this can hardly be the man referred to in ch. 33. He was away with the three legions intrusted to him, as there recorded.
militum virtute: i.e. of the infantry; the cavalry, it will be remembered, were not Romans, but Gauls and other allies.
nullo usu percepto, having gained no experience; i.e. even after seeing the successful action of the veterans.
eo consilio: with ut … defenderent in app.—permanere: compl. infin. with potuerunt.
quam: the antecedent is eam vim celeritatemque.
demiserunt: se has already been expressed with recipere.
ex inferioribus ordinibus: the officers of a new legion were usually obtained in this way, being promoted from the lower grades of veteran cohorts.
ne ante partam, etc.: notice again the esprit de corps of the Roman soldier; cf. 109 1-9, 142 7-11, 146 13 ff.
pars periit: two cohorts; see 184 26.
constitisse, etc., had now gained a position.
praeda: see 179 26.
fidem non faceret, could not make them believe.
alienata mente, beside themselves with terror.—deletis … recepisse: after dicerent.

neque: the negative belonging with oppugnaturos fuisse is, as often in Latin, combined with the general connective of the sentence.—incolumi exercitu (abl. abs. denoting condition), in case the army were safe.
oppugnaturos fuisse: the regular form in indir. disc. for oppugnavissent a contrary-to-fact apodosis.

"Brave as they were, the Roman soldiers seem to have been curiously liable to panics of this kind. The faith with which they relied upon their general avenged itself through the completeness with which they were accustomed to depend upon him. He returned on the day which he had fixed, and not unnaturally was displeased at the disregard of his orders. He did not, or does not in his Commentaries, professedly blame Cicero. But the Ciceros perhaps resented the loss of confidence which one of them had brought upon himself. Quintus Cicero cooled in his zeal, and afterwards amused the leisure of his winter quarters with composing worthless dramas."—Froude's "Caesar."
eventus (acc. plu.) belli, the fortune of war (in general).—unum, only one thing. >>>>>>> 1.5
casui: dat. with relinqui.—relinqui debuisse (§ 486.a (288.a); H. 537. 1), as usual added without any other word of saying beyond that involved in questus.
multum fortunam … potuisse: cf. 175 7 ff.
avertisset: sc. fortuna.
rerum: part. gen. with maxime.—videbatur: the subj. is quod … obtulerunt.

beneficium: i.e. by giving him opportunity to escape. He was never captured. In honor of his splendid resistance to the invader a colossal statue has lately been erected to him at Tongres; see Fig. 83.
agebatur: i.e. especially castle.—frumenta: distinguish from frumentum.
anni tempore: it was now late in the fall, but the unfortunate people had not been able to harvest their crops.
his … pereundum [esse], that these must needs perish; his is dat. of agent.
in eum locum ventum est, matters were brought to such a pass, i.e. they were so close upon him.

ut ([non] omit) … contenderent, that prisoners who were brought in looked round among their number for Ambiorix, whom they had just seen in flight—supposing that he must have been taken also—and insisted that he was not yet quite out of sight.
paene … vincerent: i.e. almost surpassed the bounds of nature in their eagerness.
summam felicitatem: i.e. complete success.—atque: almost equals but.
eriperet, peteret: in the same construction as the preceding verbs depending on ut.
damno: abl. of manner. The reference is to those killed by the German raid, chs. 37-40.
coniuratione: see chs. 3 and 4.

more maiorum: the ancient Roman mode of punishment was to flog the criminal to death, after which he was beheaded,—an extraordinary sentence to pronounce on a prisoner of war, It was this mode of punishment that was symbolized directly by the lictors' fasces. Concerted resistance (coniuratio) had come to be regarded as a flagrant crime, and its penalty was more and more bloody as time went on—as we see in the two succeeding Books.
aqua … interdixisset: i.e. banished them, forbade them to return to Gaul.
Agedinci: locative.
ad conventus agendos: cf. 48 28.

div1.head: BOOK SEVENTH.—B.C. 52.
div1.p:
WAR OF VERCINGETORIX.—The last three campaigns had been conducted wholly in the north, with a view either to crush the bolder and more restless northern populations, or to overawe the more barbarous Britons and Germans beyond the frontier. It is not quite clear why the discontented spirits of the south did not seize the occasion to join forces with the formidable Belgian revolt. At all events, they seemed quiet and submissive after their defeats in the earlier campaigns, and might have continued so but for the execution of Acco (Bk. vi. ch. 44), which had aroused the spirit of all the Gallic nobility, and the news from Rome, where the hostile aristocracy had long been waiting for some opportunity to check Caesar in his career of conquest and call him home.
This opportunity seemed to offer in the disorders which followed the death of Clodius. Clodius was a bully and professional politician belonging to the popular party, a bitter enemy of Cicero, whom he had succeeded, a few years before, in driving into exile. He was killed in a street brawl on the 20th of January of this year by Milo, a ruffian of the senatorial or aristocratic party. For the time, all regular and orderly government was at an end, till at length Pompey was invested with dictatorial powers, and quiet was restored. The news of these events coming to Gaul gave the native leaders reasonable ground to hope that a new uprising might be successful. Their plan, it will appear, was, by a sudden movement, to cut off Caesar's communications with his military posts in the north, which would thus be speedily starved into surrender. This plan Caesar foiled by striking, with his usual rapidity, through their line, and through the neutral or hostile populations of Central Gaul, and so advancing upon his assailants with the support of his legions from the north. His campaign of this year was the most fiercely contested, as well as the most important and decisive, of the entire war.
N. B.—In this book the editors have purposely abstained from grammatical comment except such as seemed necessary for the interpretation of the text; in order that the student might have one book of Caesar's Commentaries, and that one of the finest pieces of simple narrative in literature, to enjoy without trying to see how the words were parsed. Grammar is absolutely necessary for Latin, but there is much in Latin besides grammar. Intelligent reading presupposes that, but does not always have it uppermost.
READING REFERENCES ON THE UPRISING OF GAUL UNDER VERCINGETORIX.
Dodge's Caesar, chaps. 15-20.
Fowler's Julius Caesar, chap. 13.
Froude's Caesar, chap. 19.
Guizot's Hist. of France, Vol. I. pp. 56-65.
Holmes's Caesar's Conquest of Gaul, chap. 7.
Merivale's Hist. of Rome, Vol. II. chap. 12.
Mommsen's Hist. of Rome, Vol. IV. pp. 323-340.
Napoleon's Caesar, chap. 10.
Plutarch's Lives, Caesar.
Trollope's Caesar, chap. 8.

div2.p: quieta Gallia: cf. 73 3, 93 2.—in Italiam: i. e. Cisalpine Gaul.

Clodi: see note above.—ut … coniurarent (clause depending on senatus consulto): this was not an ordinary conscription, but a levy in mass, in which the entire population of Italy liable to military duty (the iuniores, between 17 and 46) took the oath of service. In addition, Caesar orders a levy throughout his own province (tota provincia), in which were included Gallia Cisalpina, Gallia Transalpina, and Illyricum.
quod … videbatur: it naturally seemed to them impossibe for Caesar to quit Italy at this crisis (urbano motu).

qui dolerent: trans. by pres. part., being indignant, etc.; the characteristic subjv. constantly has this meaning; cf. the use of cum. It approaches a causal relation, but has properly no notion of cause.—ante: adv. modifying dolerent.
principes Galliae: subj. of queruntur.—locis: loc. abl., without a prep., as usual.
Acconis: see Bk. vi. ch. 44.
qui: sc. eos, i.e. some state to begin hostilities.
capitis, of their lives; the sing. is idiomatic in Latin.
ut … intercludatur (see introductory note): depends on rationem, a plan (of campaign).
Carnutes: this name is represented by Chartres.
cavere inter se, take security from each other.—ne res efferatur: as the exchange of hostages would be a conspicuous and public act.

conlatis, etc.: an armed or symbolically armed council seems to have been the most binding form of public ratification of concerted measures. Here the standards were gathered in a sheaf and the oath taken by this symbol of unity.
deserantur: it seems to have needed the most solemn forms of agreement to bind the discordant and jealous Gauls.
Cenabum: now Orléans, on the Loire.

negotiandi: their business was money-lending, the farming of taxes, purchase of slaves or corn, and the like. Cicero had said, some years before, that business affairs in Gaul were wholly controlled by Roman citizens.
constiterant, had settled.
major atque inlustrior: i.e. than usual.
clamore: a sort of vocal telegraph, by which, as also by signal-fires, messages were conveyed, it is said, from towers 500 yards apart.
Cenabi: locative.

ante … vigiliam: between nine and ten at night; the sending of the message thus occupying about sixteen hours.—Arvernonum: i.e. the country now called Auvergne, a region always noted for the vigor and hardihood of its people, who now became leaders in the great revolt, and furnished its dauntless chief Vercingetorix.
Vercingetorix: a name or title explained as meaning "very brave lord," and well calculated (says the historian Florus) to inspire terror.
principatum, etc.: see 27 14 and last note on 2 1.
totius Galliae: i.e. all Celtic Gaul.
incendit: sc. eos.
prohibetur: conative present; i.e. they try to prevent him. This discouragement of the elders was of evil omen to his enterprise from the start.
Gergovia: the chief town cf the Arverni, on an eminence near Clermont.

perditorum: men of ruined fortunes, desperate. This is the usual course of things and the usual accusation. The well-to-do are rarely ardent patriots. When trouble comes, they either make terms or flee to the provinces.

Senones, etc.: several of these names are preserved in the modern Sens, Paris, Poitiers, Tours, Limoges. The league included all Celtic Gaul south of the Seine and west of the loyal (or doubtful) Haedui and Bituriges, who were drawn into it later on.
imperat, he levies, with acc. and dat.
quantum armorum, how many arms.
quod (interrog.): agrees witll tempus, and before what time.
necat: i.e. the offenders.
Rutenos: these, as well as the Cadurci, lay between the Arverni and the Roman province. It was important, therefore, to secure them as a frontier defence.
de consilio, by the advice.
qui: agrees with the persons implied in equitatus peditatusque, § 280 (182.a); G. 211. R. 1; H. 445. 5.
veritos: translate by a causal clause.
quibus id, etc., who they knew had this plan.
ipsi: i.e. the Bituriges.—id eane, etc., whether they did this for the reason which, etc.

quod (adv. acc.), because (the reason for non videtur, etc.). This is a bit which goes to show that the commentaries, notwithstanding their aim at political effect, are substantially true. Caesar was too great a man to deceive others except when he deceived himself.
virtute = vigor. This word is in Latin often used in a vague sense equivalent to our 'thanks to' or the like.
qua … posset: indir. quest. following difficultate, which implies doubt.
se absente: Caesar knew well his own influence over his army. See also introductory notes.—dimicaturas [esse]: sc. eas, i.e. the legions.
ipse, etc.: the most submissive Gauls at such a time were not to be depended upon, if they had the slightest chance to capture him.— eis: indir. obj. of committi, the subj. of which is suam salutem.
Lucterius, etc.: an officer of Vercingetorix; see 189 1. He endeavored to rouse the border tribes against the Romans, but was checked by the promptness and farsightedness of Caesar.
Nitiobriges et Gabalos: these completed the Arvernian frontier, the Volcae and Helvii being within the limits of the Province.
Narbonem, Narbonne, the chief town of Gallia Narbonensis, founded by C. Gracchus.
antevertendum [esse] has for its subj. ut … proficisceretur, and is followed by the dat. consiliis.
provincialibus: a portion of the Ruteni had been incorporated in the Province.
quod … putabat: referring to Lucterius.
Cevenna: the pass crossing this range is about 4000 feet high.

durissimo, etc.: Pompey was put in authority February 25 (by the old calendar, which was now about six weeks ahead of the actual time); Caesar, who left Italy directly after, probably crossed the Cevennes about the middle of January.
summo labore: "these admirable soldiers were worthy of the genius of their chief," but such men as Caesar and Napoleon make that kind of soldiers.
singulari homini, a solitary wayfarer, to say nothing of an army.
at: marks a transition as usual; translate meanwhile.
usu … praeceperat, had suspected would come to pass.—per causam, on the pretext (so elsewhere in Caesar): his real motive was to join his force.
Brutum: Decimus Junius Brutus, afterward one of Caesar's assassins. This same officer had command of the fleet in the famous battle with the Veneti; see 82 7-10.
triduo: this was a pretence, and was given out to conceal his real design.
Viennam, Vienne, a little below Lyons on the Rhone.—recentem: i.e. they were well rested and in good condition for a forced march.
hiemabant: see Bk. vi. ch. 44. His route would lie due north up the Saône along the eastern line of the Haedui. The distance of this rapid winter journey was above 300 miles.—quid: with consili.
de sua salute, affecting his own safety; opposed to any design on his forces.
reliquas, etc.: two of them were somewhere near Luxembourg, and six at Sens, about 140 miles apart.
prius: with quam.—unum locum: evidently Sens.
Gorgobinam: this was situated probably on the Allier, a southern confluent of the Loire.
Haeduis attribuerat: see 25 19 ff.
difficultatem: the dilemma in which Caesar finds himself is expressed by the two parallel conditions, si … contineret, ne … deficeret, and si … educeret, ne … laboraret.
stipendiariis: i.e. the Boii, who were tributaries of the Haedui.
amicis, etc., since his friends would find there was no help for them in him.
ab, in respect to his supply of corn.
Agedinci: now Sens, the chief town of the Senones.

altero die, on the second day of the march.—Vellaunodunum: the position of this town is somewhat uncertain, but Caesar apparently did not march directly towards Gorgobina, but made a detour towards the north in order to cross the Loire at Orléans.
quo, in order that.
circumvallavit: the circumvallation consisted of a line of wall and trench surrounding the town.
iter: i.e. to the relief of the Boii at Gorgobina.

qui tum primum, etc.: i. e. they had just heard of the invest-
ment of Vellaunodunum and, thinking the siege would last longer, were raising a force to defend their chief town about 120 miles off.
eam rem: i.e. the siege.
quod mitterent, to send, giving the purpose of comparabant.
in posterum: sc. diem.
militibus imperat, he orders the soldiers to prepare. The dir. obj. of imperat being a demonstrative antecedent of quae, not expressed in Latin, and in Eng. absorbed in 'what.'
contingebat, touched: i. e. led directly to. The town being on the north bank, the bridge would allow its defenders to cross to the friendly Bituriges.
desideratis quin, etc.: a loose use of the quin-construction; all, with very few exceptions, were captured.
diripit: cf. the fate of Avaricum, ch. 28.
ille: i.e. Caesar.
Noviodunum: the position is uncertain. Caesar's march, however, was certainly to the south up the Loire. This town is to be distinguished from Noviodunum of ch. 55, a city of the Haedui.
celeritate: we may supply in Eng. a demon. as antecedent to qua.
novi aliquid consili, some new design.
omnīs incolumīs: see l. 15 above; construe with receperunt, got their men all back safe to Caesar's camp.

Germanos: this force was much superior to the Gallic cavalry, and was destined to turn the battle in Caesar's favor at many critical times; see chs. 67, 70, 80. The tactics of the German cavalry are described 43 4 ff.
ab initio: the meaning of this is not clear. He had no German cavalry at the beginning of his campaigns. He may have obtained them after his struggle with Ariovistus.
quibus, and these (the Gallic horse).
eos (obj. of perduxerunt): i.e. the leaders in the sudden movement described above, ch. 12.
Avaricum: the modern Bourges, an important town of 40,000 inhabitants, the geographical centre of France.
longe alla ratione atque, in a way quite diffeffent from, etc.; by purely defensive or guerilla war.
anni tempore: i.e. scarcely yet spring, long before harvest; all supplies must be got from granaries or storehouses (aedificia), which might easily be destroyed.
hos omnīs: i.e. hostis.
incendi: cf. the course of the Helvetians, Bk. i. ch. 5.
hoc spatio: explained by quo, etc., i.e. the range of the Roman foraging parties.—[a Boia]: omit.
quorum: the antecedent is eorum.
neque interesse, and it makes no difference [he says].—ne … an, whether … or.
sint receptacula, serve as retreats.

neu, and lest, sc. sint from preceding clause.—proposita, offered to be captured by the Romans. The method of warfare here advised by Vercingetorix and afterwards consistently followed by him stamps him as a general of first-rate ability. We may fitly compare Fabius Maximus harassing and weakening the army of Hannibal, and the burning of Moscow by the Russians to drive out Napoleon.
urbīs: Caesar more commonly calls them oppida. Rome alone is always urbs.
solaci: part. gen. with hoc.
amissa, all they had lost (obj. of recuperaturos).
incendi, etc.: a double indir. quest., whether … or.
flumine: the city was just above the junction of the Auron with the Yèvre.
volgi: obj. gen., i.e. his compassion for the poor people, who would be turned out of house and home in the winter, if the town should be burned.
longe, distant.—certos (cerno), regular.
in … tempora, from hour to hour.
etsi, etc., although so far as skillful planning (ratione) could provide (against this danger), our men took the precaution of going at uncertain times and in different directions.
ut … iretur: a clause of purpose, taking its construction from provideri though not immediately connected with it. The verbs are used impersonally.
quae … habebat: i. e. the neck of the peninsula on which the town was situated (196 8 ff.).
intermissa, left free.—[a]: omit.

aggerem, etc.: see chapter on military affairs, VIII.
Between the Yèvre and the Auron was a plateau, some 1200 to 1600 feet high, with rather steep banks.As this plateau approached the town, it narrowed to a ridge only about 400 feet wide, with the Auron on one side and a swampy brook, the Yvrette, on the other. From the Yévrette to the Yèvre extended a morass. At a distance of about 300 feet from the city wall the ridge was intersected by a sudden depression like a trench, perhaps 50 feet deep (see plan, Fig. 90). Caesar pitched his camp on the
plateau just back of the ridge, a little over half a mile from Avaricum. Along the ridge, right across the intersecting ravine, he built the agger.
alteri: the Haedui, already wavering in their allegiance; alteri: the Boii, a fragment of the defeated Helvetians (Bk. i. ch. 28).
ab eis: the source of vox, not the agent of audita. Notice again in this passage the invincible endurance of these soldiers.
ignominiae loco, in the place of (i.e. as) a disgrace.
Cenabi: locative.
parentarent = ut parentarent, the natural construction. As one might say irregularly in English 'It is better to suffer anything than not avenge our comrades,' omitting 'to.'
qui … consuessent: see Bk. i. ch. 48.
sarcinas, etc.: the regular preparation for battle.
difficilis, hard to cross; impedita, embarrassing; the two words express only different phases of the same idea.
fiducia loci, trusting to the strength of the position.
[in civitatis]: omit.—vada [ac saltus], fords and open spaces, where the way seemed practicable.

haesitantīs, struggling in the mud or bushes.—premerent: a purpose clause, taking its construction from sic animo parati, determined; cf. 199 3, where the same words take a result clause. The two constructions approach each other, but the first refers to future time, the last to present.

propinquitatem: i.e. the armies were separated only by the swamp.—videret: the contrast is between the casual observer and the careful inspector (qui … perspiceret).—prope, etc., on nearly equal terms; iniquitatem, unfair advantage, showing that their offering battle was inanis simulatio.
quod … possent: follows indignantīs, chafing that, etc.—conspectum suum, the sight of them.
necesse sit, etc., a victory must needs cost, with the abl. of price.
iniquitatis: § 352 (220); G. 378; H. 409. II.
proditionis: see last note.
discessisset and venissent refer to the action in ch. 13.—imperio = imperatore.
non haec, etc., all these things could not, they said.
illum: connect with malle habere.
ipsorum: sc. concessu.
persuasum [esse]: impers., that it had been recommended.—qui se … defenderet, which was its own defence (ch. 19).
fortunae (dat.): as well as huic (referring to alicuius), to be construed with habendam gratiam, thanks were due.
imperium: the same as regnum Galliae above.
quin etiam, nay even. Distinguish carefully from quin introducing a neg. result.—remittere, is ready to resign; in dir. disc., remitto, I resign.—si = [to see] whether (ind. quest.).
nec iam viris, etc., that no one any longer has sufficient strength; viris is from vis.
posse: sc. quemquam, supplied from cuiusquam.
[Vercingetorix]: may be omitted.
quem: construe with ne … recipiat, subj. of provisum est, and as it basely flees from this spot, I have provided that no state shall receive it within its boundaries.
suo more: cf. Tacitus (Ger. II), si placuit sententia, frameas concutiunt.
in eo, in the case of him.
summum: this word is often used where we should say "a great."
maiore ratione, with better generalship.
si … retinuissent: in app. with eo (that condition).
genus: i. e. the Gauls.
atque … aptissimum: cf. Bk. iv. ch. 5; atque connects the descriptive gen. summae sollertiae and the descriptive adj. aptissimum.
laqueis, etc.: see Fig. 127.
cum destinaverant, … reducebant: a general condition expressing repeated action in past time; cf. 130 7.
ferrariae: so of the copper mines of the Aquitani; see 89 11-18.

cotidianus agger: i.e, the daily increase in the height of the agger.—commissis malis, by splicing the upright timbers; these were the high corner beams of the towers, by which they were raised in successive stages, so that each increase in the height of the Roman works was met by a corresponding increase in the height of the defences. The towers on the walls were probably connected by covered galleries, one for each story.

apertos cuniculos … morabantur, etc.: this refers to the obstructions put by the Gauls in the way of the open passage ways which ran through the agger, and which the soldiers used in carrying material for its advance and completion; morabantur has the force of blocked or obstructed. See Figs. 92, 93, 120, and chapter on military affairs, VIII.
directae, at right angles with the course of the wall.—perpetuae in longitudinem, along the whole length.
revinciuntur, are fastened by beams some forty feet in length, running lengthwise of the wall.
intervalla: i.e. the two feet between each two of the beams in the lower tier (ordo).

ut idem, etc., in such a way that the same space (between the beams) is preserved, and that the beams do not touch each other; but, placed at equal intervals, the individual beams are firmly bound together by the corresponding stones placed between them; i.e. so alternating in the successive layers that beams rested on stone, and stone on beams.
cum: correlative with tum below.
quadragenum: note the distributive, forty each.
introrsus revincta: i.e. the beams were mortised together at some distance from the exposed ends, making it next to impossible to force them apart; see Fig. 94.
frigore: it was still very early in the year, scarcely spring; see 208 10.

latum: as a width of over 300 feet is incredible, some have supposed that this is an error for longum; others, that the numeral should be xxxx.—altum pedes lxxx: it must be remembered that the height of the agger had to equal the depth of the ravine it crossed, and also the height of the Gallic wall. The latter may have been thirty feet.
cuniculo: i.e. a mine running under the agger. It should be remembered that the agger was built largely of wood.
turrium: the Roman towers, mounted on wheels or rollers, and here referring to those flanking the agger; see Figs .43, 92, 127.
partitis temporibus: i.e. in their turn.
reducerent: i.e. out of reach of the fire.
interscinderent: i.e. they cut away the unfinished end of the agger, which was in flames. Thus the rest was saved.

pluteos: here the high wooden bulwarks (loricae) protecting each story of the tower:
Figure 129. Pluteus. Modern restoration.
Figure 130. Pluteus. Modern restoration. see note on 144 2.
nec … animadvertebant, and noticed that the exposedmen did not readily approach to give assistance.

accidit, etc., an incident occurred before my eyes, which, seem-
ing worthy of record, I thought ought not to be omitted. Observe the use of the plural pronoun, the 'editorial we', extremely common in Latin.
per manus traditas: i.e. his companions passed them to him to throw.
scorpione: this was a powerful cross-bow, for hurling darts or bolts; see chapter on military affairs, I. 5 and Fig. 95.
palus: probably the watery valley of the Auron.
suorum, their husbands.
quos: refers to se as well as to liberos.
quo timore: the regular Latin idiom where we should expect cuius rei timore.

[intra vineas]: it would be impossible for legions to find room inside the vineae. Either legiones here refers to the storming columns, or intra vineas means within the line of the sheds, and so out of sight. Many editors omit the words altogether.—expeditis, put in fighting order.
adscendissent: informal indir. disc. for the fut. perf. of the direct.
cuneatim, in a compact body; (lit. wedge-fashion) implying tactics like those of the Romans.
si qua … veniretur, if an attack should be made from any side; [contra] may be omitted; veniretur is impersonal.
circumfundi (impers. pass.) = that men were pouring in.
continenti impetu, without stopping.
exitu: abl. of cause.
quisquam: i.e. Romanorum.—Cenabensi caede: see ch. 3.

[ut]: omit.—procul in via, etc., placing his friends and the chiefs of the states at intervals for some distance along the road, he took care that they [the fugitives] should be separated and conducted to their own people.
quae … pars = ad eam partem … quae and refers to the persons implied by suos, and is explained by 198 7, where it is said that the Gallic forces were arranged generatim.
consolatus cohortatusque: the fall of Avaricum must have been a crushing blow to Vercingetorix, but he meets the disaster with a magnificent courage.
errare si qui = that those were mistaken who, etc.
sibi numquam placuisse: see 196 3-13.
quae … dissentirent: i.e. the states that had not yet joined the rebellion.
effectum habere: see notes on 13 4, 40 20, 51 8.
impetrari, etc.: i.e. he had a right to ask them to proceed to fortify, etc.; notice the modesty of these words, appropriate to the great disaster just suffered.
re integra, before anything had happened (see ch. 15).
ut … sic: correlatives.
de reliquis, etc.: follows in spem, hope of, etc.
homines insueti: an appositive expressing concession; translate by although.
capere, gain over (the neutral states).
armandos vestiendosque: gerundives expressing purpose, agreeing with the understood obj. [eos] of curat; cf. 11 5, 82 7.
quem: sc. numerum.
sagittarios: apparently the Gauls had trusted too much, especially during the siege, to hand-to-hand fighting.
quos conduxerat, whom he had hired; i.e. mercenaries.
confecta: it was now about the end of March, or a little later.—tempore: i.e. the time was suitable for campaigning.
sive … sive: understand to try, or some such phrase to introduce these clauses which are treated as indir. questions.
maxime necessario tempore, in an extreme emergency.
proximo anno, the year before.
suas … clientelas, that each of them had his own [armed] followers (see Bk. vi. ch. 15).
quod si, but if; see second note on 40 20.
positum [esse], depended on.
minus [sibi] confideret, felt itself weakest.
eis: dat. with liceret.
quos inter = eos inter quos.
atque, than, as often after alius.—oportuerit: for oportuit of the direct, implying the nonfulfilment of the duty; see § 522.a (311.c); G. 597. R. 3; H. 511. I. N. 3.

renuntiatum: renuntiare is the technical term for the act of a magistrate who, after an election, formally declares the result, and thus "creates" the new official. In this case one brother had declared the other elected after a sham election by an illegal convention.—vivo utroque, when both are living.

intermissis magistratibus, there being a vacancy in the magistracy; this phrase signifies that an interval occurred between the term of one magistrate and the due election of his successor. Valetiacus (208 22) had illegally appointed his brother Cotus to be his successor. The priests
promptly declared the office vacant and appointed Convictolitavis to fill the position until a regular election could again be held. In such a case at Rome (as had recently occurred twice, B.C. 55 and 52),the patrician senators appointed an interrex by virtue of the sacred authority residing in them. Caesar here, accordingly, recognizes the likeness to a Roman precedent.
obtinere, to hold against (ob) the rival claimant. See note on 2 1.
[his]: makes sense and may be translated.
quae = ut ea: purpose.
ducendas: cf. 206 12.
secundum flumen, along the stream (construe with duxit).
ab altera parte: Caesar being on the right or eastern bank, Vercingetorix on the western, on which the town of Gergovia lay.
e regione: see vocab.; cf. 204 5.—castris: dat. of reference.
partem: acc. of extent of time.
rescindendos: cf. 209 27.
distractis, etc.: this means that Caesar made up two sham legions by taking cohorts from the others, so that there might appear to be six full legions as before.

perventum [esse] (impers.): i.e. that the four legions that had gone on ahead had reached their camping ground.—pars inferior: the lower end of the piles, which (being under water) was not burned or cut away, served as a support to the new bridge hastily constructed for the crossing.
magnis itineribus: see note on 8 22.
quintis castris, at the fifth encampment, or end of the fifth day's march.
situ: see plan, Fig. 97.
oppugnatione, taking (it) by storm, without a formal siege.— de obsessione, etc.: i.e. he concluded not to invest it regularly until supplies had been provided.
qua despici poterat, where a view could be had from above.
seu quid, etc., in case any communication or orders should seem necessary.
quid: with animi ac virtutis (part. gen.).

collis: the so-called Roche Blanche (White Rock), at whose foot flows the only sufficient stream of water (see plan, Fig. 97). Caesar's larger camp, it will be observed, lay toward the southeast of the town, and the smaller towards the south; while the forces of the Gauls lay on the
gentler southern slopes of the hill (measuring nearly a mile from east to west, and a third as much from north to south) on which the town was built (see ch. 46).
quem si, etc.: fut. condition, indir. disc.
et … et: correlatives.
tamen: opposed to the whole description, not to the last part merely.
posset: see note on 158 24. The verb is here impersonal.
demonstravimus: see 209 17-19.
praemium communicat: i.e. the money received from the Arverni.
imperio natos, born for command (dat.).—unam, etc., was the only thing, etc., though unam as usual agrees with the pred.
traducta, carried over to the patriotic party.
beneficio, a friendly act; i.e. deciding the magistracy in his favor.—sic … obtinuerit: i.e. this (he claimed) was only his due and not a special favor.
vel principes, even leaders, not mere followers or adherents.
placuit, it was decided.—milibus: this refers to the troops that Caesar had asked for against Vercingetorix; see 209 23-25.
ea ducenda curaret, that he should have charge of their march.
reliqua: subj. of agi, the whole clause being the obj. of constituunt.
principes civitatis: see ch. 39.
consili res, a matter for deliberation.—sit: for mood and tense, see § 524 (312); G. 602; H. 513. II.
una (adv.), with him.—frumenti: i.e. which these Romans were taking to Caesar under the protection of the Haeduan guard.
genere dispari, of lower birth.
traditum: here equivalent to commendatum,—presented as suited for public service.
nominatim, etc.: i. e. he had sent them a personal summons.
quod … provideat, which he foresees will be the consequence.
levi momento, of light account; momentum (from moveo) is strictly the weight which "moves" the balance scale.

contrahenda: as only two legions were left behind, the camp should have been "contracted," so that these few might be equal to the task of keeping and relieving guard. The danger to which the situation exposed them is related in the next chapter,—propter magnitudinem castrorum, l. 26.
fratres: these had gone to Caesar in advance of the Haeduan force; see 212 13. They seem to have suspected, or to have been warned, that the plot had been betrayed.
necessario … labore, by the hardship of a forced march. It is worth while to notice the frank terms on which Caesar stands with his citizen-soldiers. This was an essential element of his success.
quos … existimabant: owing to the falsehoods of Litavicus, 212 17-20.
quibus nefas est, for whom it is wrong; see Bk. iii. ch. 22.
[noctis]: if this word is authentic, it must refer to the early part of the night, for Caesar marches back to his camp, a distance of twenty-five miles, before sunrise.
quibus isdem: dat. of apparent agent after permanendum esset. The thought is that the soldiers were so few that the same men had to do all the fighting and could not be relieved.
tormenta: see chapter on military affairs, I. 5.—discessu eorum: at the suspension of their attack when night came on; his messengers had apparently set out about midnight.
obstruere, etc.: these pres. infinitives show that his preparations were still going on.—pluteos vallo addere: to make a defence behind which the soldiers could stand while manning the wall.

ante ortum solis, etc.: Caesar left his camp a little after midnight, marched twenty-five miles, gave his soldiers a rest of three hours, and marched back twenty-five miles, reaching camp before sunrise, having been away but little more than twenty-four hours; truly a remarkable display of energy.
levem auditionem: see 97 6-9.—pro re comperta, as an ascertained fact.
proclinatam: "leaning forward" like a wall just ready to fall = perilous as it was (in itself).
fide data, giving pledges of security.
idem facere: i.e. to come out and put themselves in their power.
omnis eorum milites: i.e. the contingent sent under Litavicus, ch. 38.
suorum: i.e. their soldiers.
capti, etc., tempted (as they had been) by the profit of the plunder.—ea res: i.e. responsibility for it.
nihil se gravius de civitate iudicare, that he thought none the worse of the state.
a, away from (the neighborhood of).
contraheret: i.e. join his forces with the four legions of Labienus, 209 26.

dorsum, etc.: the hill (collis) was southwest of the town and northwest of Caesar's smaller camp (see plan); while from it a narrow wooded ridge (dorsum), nearly level, gave easy access to the town at its western side. Most of the Gallic force had been transferred to that side from the eastern and southern defences. This left the Gallic camps and the part of the city opposite the Romans bare of defenders.
uno … occupato: see 211 11-21.
quin … viderentur: after aliter sentire (= dubitare); cf. 213 3.
hunc: i.e. alterum collem.
impedimentorum (= iumentorum) beasts of burden.
stramenta, the pack-saddles, which would prevent the animal from being ridden conveniently.

collibus (loc. abl.) circumvehi: i.e. towards the westerly side. All these movements were designed to make the Gauls fear an attack from the west or northwest. Caesar's real design was to make a sudden dash from the south and east and surprise their camps.
easdem regiones: i.e. in the vicinity of the hill which the Gauls were fortifying.
ut contineant, etc.: i.e. the design was not to hold the camp, but simply to sweep through it by a sudden and daring raid.
ab dextra parte: i.e. from the larger camp to the east.
recta regione, in a straight line.
si … intercederet … aberat: construction analogous to § 517.c (308.c. cf. N. 2); G. 597. 3; H. 511. I. N. 3.
huc, to this amount.
in longitudinem ut … ferebat, lengthwise of the hill.
murum: traces of this wall are still found, at some distance down the slope, parallel with the town wall.

inferiore omni, etc.: i.e. the space below the six-foot wall to the bottom of the ascent, a distance of about half a mile, was vacant; the space above to the city wall, also about half a mile, was filled with the Gallic encampments.
castris: the separate camps of the several Gallic states, set close together, of which three (trinis) were taken.
ad munitionem: i.e. ad murum a medio colle.

legionis: with signa. Observe that Caesar is found, as usual, with his favorite legion; cf. 36 21-25. This legion, it will
be remembered (217 25), was first stationed some distance away from the others. It seems to have returned and taken a prominent part in the assault.
reliquarum: i.e. those engaged in the assault just described.
retinebantur: conative; the officers tried to hold them back.
Avarici: see 206 3-5.
quem … constabat, who, it was certain, said that day in the presence of his soldiers. The subj. of constabat is quem … dixisse.
prius quisquam, any body before him.
supra: see 217 26 ff.
oppidum … teneri: depends on nuntiis as a word of telling.
sub muro: i.e. below and outside of the city wall.
cursu: they had run about a mile up a steep ascent.

sub infimo colle: at the foot of the hill on which was the smaller Roman camp (211 11-21), see Fig. 97 (Sextius, 1st position).—ab … hostium: i.e. on the Roman left; Caesar, meanwhile, was posted considerably to the right (eastward).
hostes: translate as if the obj. of terreret.—quo … insequerentur: expresses the purpose of terreret.
progressus: it was rather a retreat than an advance; see plan, Fig. 97 (Leg. x, 2d position).
latere aperto, the exposed flank of the Romans; i.e. the right flank.
manus distinendae causa: i.e. to make a diversion.
insigne pactum, the signal agreed upon. The Haedui had their Gallic arms and standards, so that the mistake was a natural one, especially at such a time of excitement.
excīdere, to cut away; i.e. from within, to gain his escape.
aequiore loco, on more level ground, farther back from the town; see plan, Fig. 97 (Leg. x, 3d position).
locum superiorem, higher ground, in the direction of the larger camp; see plan, Fig. 97 (2d position of Sextius). The retreat was made in good order, as is shown by what immediately follows.
cupiditatem, eagerness for battle.
ad Avaricum: referring to the operations in that neighborhood described in ch. 19.
quanto opere … tanto opere: correlatives.
eadem, etc.: i.e. that the wisest course would be to join his forces with those of Labienus, in view of all the troubles that were threatening; cf. 216 4-8.

nihilo magis: Vercingetorix was far too wary and skilful to
put himself at such disadvantage. He knew that he was no match for Caesar on level ground. An interesting parallel might be drawn between the tactics of Vercingetorix and those of Fabius the Delayer against Hannibal.

secundo, favorable to the Romans. By this slight success and the refusal of Vercingetorix to meet him in the plain on even terms, Caesar avoids the appearance of a compulsory retreat. Still, it is evident that Caesar's operations against Gergovia were far from being as successful as he himself had hoped or wished. It was the only city that defied his assault successfully, and its victorious resistance must have been a great encouragement to the Gallic patriots.

Viridomaro, etc.: see 213 13-17. These young Haeduan nobles had decided to desert Caesar, and so, as soon as they reached the frontier of their country, on the east side of the Allier, they invented an excuse for leaving him.
perfidiam … habebat: see note on coactum habebat, 13 4.
discedentibus (dat.), as they were setting out.

quos et quam humilis, in what a state (lit. whom) and how humbled; shortly before Caesar's arrival in Gaul the Sequani with the Germans as their allies had conquered the Haedui and imposed heavy conditions on them. See Bk. i. ch. 31.
mandatis: this word implies that what he has just said to them is to be repeated to their countrymen at home.
Noviodunum: the modern Nevers, on the right bank of the Loire (Liger), just above its junction with the Allier (Elaver). The Noviodunum of ch. 12 is probably Sancerre.
civitatis: the Haeduan commonwealth. The status is described in the clause which follows, down to missos.
Bibracte: loc. abl.
tantum commodum: i.e. of taking the town, seizing the Roman stores, and especially of capturing the hostages, whose possession was all important to Caesar for keeping the tribes in subjection.
cui: indef. pron. with usui.

in provinciam: Caesar was now on the western or further bank of the Loire, which he would thus be obliged to follow up towards its source, thence crossing over to the province. The bracketed words may be translated.
nivibus: it was still spring, perhaps about May.
si esset, etc., in case (i.e. lest) he might have to risk a battle while the bridge-building was under way.
eo: i.e. on the Loire. Caesar felt that to effect a union with Labienus as soon as possible was vitally important.
ne … converteret: depending on impediebat.
ut non nemo, as many a one.
cum: correl. with tum.

Labieno, legionibus: datives following timebat. For the facts, see 209 26 ff. The situation was extremely critical, and it is not strange that many thought Caesar would have to desert Labienus and seek safety for himself in the province. Most men would have done so, but Caesar was a man apart, an extraordinary military genius.
admodum, etc.: these marches must have been extraordinary, to judge from the expression.
pro rei necessitate, considering the emergency, difficult and hazardous as it was.

disposito equitatu: i.e. just above the ford a line of cavalry was formed in the water, reaching across the river. By this barrier the violence of the current was checked. Another line also was stationed below the ford to catch any that were swept away.
eo supplemento: see 186 3-5, 190 9-12.
Lutetiam: see 159 3 and note.
Aulerco: this tribe was the next westerly, south of the Seine (see map, Fig. 88).
is: i.e. Camulogenus.

perpetuam paludem: the marsh ground along the little river Essonne, which flows into the Seine on tile south a little above Paris. Labienus was proceeding on the left or southerly bank of the Seine. See plan, Fig. 99.
aggere, a mass of earth for a causeway.
Metiosedum (or Melodunum) Melun: here Labienus crosses to the north or right bank.
eo, aboard (= in eas).
secundo flumine, following the river-course down the right bank. Having boats or pontoons, he would easily cross the Marne just above Paris.
palude: a marshy ground south of the river.
confirmabant, kept asserting.
qui refers to Bellovaci.—per se: i.e. without this example of the Haedui.
neque: connects intellegebat and cogitabat. The latter verb is here followed by two clauses of purpose, The infin. would be more usual.

altera, alteram: the Bellovaci were on the north of the Seine; Camulogenus (ch. 57) was on the south.—quae civitas: the defection of this tribe might well cause Labienus uneasiness. They were a nation of warriors and could put 100,000 men in the field. When the tribes of Belgic Gaul conspired against Caesar, the Bellovaci, because of their importance, were placed at the head of the league; see 51 11-15.
praesidio: at Agedincum (Sens) on the other side of the Seine; see 224 23-26.
ab animi virtute: a truly Roman quality, of which, fortunately, Labienus had a good supply.
equitibus: not cavalrymen, but unattached officers of equestrian rank (tribuni militum, comites imperatoris, etc.) put in charge each of a single vessel.
adverso flumine: a feint, the real attack being made below.—imperat, gives orders (followed by the acc. and infin. instead of the usual ut-clause).
exercitus equitatusque: thought of as one body, hence with a sing. verb.
tumultuari: the magno tumultu of l. 15.
paulo infra: about four miles below.
Omit the bracketed words.
castrorum: the Roman camp.
naves: i.e. the linitris of 227 16, not the ships, for they had gone the other way.
ostenderunt: sc. tribuni.

neque potuerunt, but could not. Much of Caesar's success was due to the excellence of his officers. In this case, for example, Labienus does not supinely wait for Caesar to come and extricate him from his difficulties, but by a military exploit of the first rank rescues himself and goes to the help of his chief.
circummittuntur, etc.: these are the acts of the Haedui.
quos Caesar, etc.: see 223 9, 22.—supplicio: i.e. by threats; cf. 188 22-28.
rationes communicet: not simply consult, but share the direction of affairs.
illi: i.e. the Remi (see Bk. ii. ch. 5; 154 3-5) and the Lingones.
requirunt = recall with regret.
summae spei, of high ambition (213 13-20).
ipse: i.e. Vercingetorix.
huc: at Bibracte, the capital of the Haedui.
factu: supine after perfacile, § 510 (303); G. 436; H. 547.
aequo animo, without complaint.—modo … corrumpant, only let them, etc.: a hortatory subjv. expressing a kind of proviso.
finitimi: see map, Fig. 2.
[ei] may be omitted.

altera ex parte: as the Roman frontier was bent into an irregular curve by the line of the Cevennes, the Gauls would strike the Province in two directions, the Haedui from the north, the Ruteni, etc., from the west; see map, Fig. 2.—Allobrogibus: these and the peoples mentioned in the next sentence were allies or subjects of Rome, and would look to Caesar for protection if attacked; see 231 5 ff.
superiore bello: the war of eight years before, in which the Allobroges had been subdued by Pomptinus (Bk. i. ch. 6).
cohortium: not legionary troops, but auxiliaries levied in the Province.
L. Caesare: a cousin of Julius, consul B.C. 64.
ad omnīs, etc., were arrayed against the enemy in every quarter.
Donnotauro: a brother of Procillus (42 10); the Roman name (C. Valerius) is regularly taken in compliment to his Roman patronus (see also 17 9, 48 10-20).
muros, strongholds—not simply the walls of the oppida.
interclusis, etc.: from this we see how much Caesar was hampered and weakened by the skilful plan of campaign that Vercingetorix employed against him.
equites: the German cavalry were far superior to the Gallic; see 193 23 ff. and note.
inter eos proeliari: see 43 4 ff., 95 15-20.
equis: for a description of these, see 95 10-14.
[sed et]: these words should probably be omitted.
equites: see 229 25.

per … finīs: bearing from near Agedincum (where he had been joined by Labienus, ch. 62) toward the east, and so leaving the hostile Haedui to the south. This movement, checked by the attack of Vercingetorix, explains how the crisis of the campaign came to be the siege and capture of Alesia (see map, Fig. 88).
parum profici, that little advantage was gained.—reversuros [esse]: i.e. Romanos.
adoriantur: for adoriamur in dir. disc., let us charge upon them.—si pedites, etc., the attack was to be made on the baggage train, which was guarded by cavalry.
Vercingetorix knew Caesar's weakness in this arm, and did not suspect the German reinforcement. If the infantry stopped to assist the cavalry (suis) the march would be delayed.
magis futurum, is more likely.

dignitate, etc.: i.e. the dishonor of retreat with loss of baggage.—nam de equitibus, etc.: i.e. even the Gauls whom he was addressing could not suppose that the Roman cavalry would wish an engagement.
quin … audeat follows ne … dubitare: i.e. even they themselves would admit that, etc.
id quo … animo, that they (i.e. the Gauls) may do so (i.e. attack the Romans) with greater courage.
pro castris, in front of the camp, by way of defiance, to support by a demonstration the attack of the cavalry.
confirmari oportere, that they ought to bind themselves.
a primo agmine, at the front of the (Roman) line of march.
aciem converti: by a change of front, turning the line of march to a line of battle.
Germani: it is evident that the victory was due to them ; cf. ch. 13.
flumen: the Vingeanne, and its tributary the Badin, about which many ornaments, weapons, etc., have been found.
proximis comitiis: i.e. of the Haedui for chief magistrate.
quo duce, etc. (see Bk. i. ch. 31): this was seemingly another Eporedorix, not the rival of Viridomarus.

Alesiam: this famous fortress (now called Alise Ste. Reine) was on the territory lying just north of the Haeduan frontier. Its natural advantages—summed up in the succeeding chapters—are thus described:

"Alesia, like Gergovia, is on a hill sloping off all round, with steep and, in places, precipitous sides. It lies between two small rivers, both of which fall into the Brenne, and thence into the Seine. Into this peninsula, witih the rivers on each side of him, Vercingetorix had thrown himself with 80,000 men. Alesia as a position was impregnable except to famine. The water supply was secure. The position was of extraordinary strength. The rivers formed natural trenches. Below the town, to the west, they ran parallel for three miles through an open alluvial plain before they reached the Brenne. In every other direction rose rocky hills of equal height with the central plateau, originally perhaps one wide tableland, through which the water had ploughed out the valley. To attack Ver-
cingetorix where he had placed himself was out of the question; but to blockade him there, to capture the leader of the insurrection and his whole and so in one blow mal;e an end with it, on a survey of the situation seemed not impossible."—Froude's "Caesar." See plan, Fig. 103.
loco: in app. with colle; cf. § 282.d (184.c); G. 411. 3; H. 363. 4. 2.

sub muro, etc.: this sentence is an excellent example, at the same time, both of the natural precedence of the relative in Latin and of the freedom of all real language from grammatical trammels. The student should first translate it literally thus: Under the wall, which side of the hill (i.e. the side which) faced the east all this space the forces of the Gauls had filled, and had carried along a ditch, etc. The meaning of this is obvious, but it is not at all in accordance with our English idiom. Indeed, it is not strictly grammatical in any language. After the student has seen what it means, he should try to put it into some form that is allowable in English idiom, say: Under the wall, the side … , all this space the forces … , and had made there, etc.
munitionis: Caesar constructed a line of contravallation; i.e. a series of works entirely surrounding the town, so as to resist a sortie.
milia : acc. of extent; tenebat having here the force of pertinebat.—castra, etc.: in the remains of these works traces have been found of four infantry and four cavalry camps (see plan, Fig. 102).
